member.name: M:Triton.Utilities.Configuration.XmlConfiguration.GetConfig(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns an XmlConfiguration object containing the child nodes specified by the input parameters

remarks.P: This method looks under the current node context for a node named section. If found, it then looks for any child elements that contain a node with an attribute called name that have a value as defined by the name parameter. If found, then the section node is returned. If either the section node or the subnode with the name attribute value are not found, Null is returned
Note: if multiple matches are possible in the XML, only the first match is returned.

member.param: String that specifies the XML node name to search
String that specifies the value of the name attribute to match
member.returns: XmlConfiguration object with the identified XML node as the root node, or Null if not found

member.name: T:Triton.Logic.CompareAction
member.summary: Action to compare the value of a request item to a given value.
member.remarks:
Returned events: equal - the object/property's value is equal to the given value.
lessthan - the object/property's value is less than the given value.
greaterthan - the object/property's value is greater than the given value.
novalue - a property value in the object's property path was null.
error - an error occurred while attempting to compare object's value.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: M:Triton.Logic.CompareAction.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor to set the property defaults.

member.name: P:Triton.Logic.CompareAction.ObjectItemNameIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the item in Request.Items containing the object to use to compare against the given value. The object itself is used for the comparison if no ObjectPropertyNameIn is provided, or a property (or nested property) of the object if ObjectPropertyNameIn is provided.

member.name: P:Triton.Logic.CompareAction.ObjectPropertyNameIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the property of the object identified by the ObjectItemNameIn attribute to be compared. The property may be of a nested object where ObjectPropertyNameIn would be the path of the desired property, for example, PropertyA.PropertyB.PropertyC. If ObjectPropertyNameIn is not provided, the object identified by ObjectItemNameIn is used directly.

member.name: P:Triton.Logic.CompareAction.CompareValueIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the value to compare the object/property value against. This may be the name of a request parameter specified by placing the parameter name within [ ], for example, [paramName].

member.name: T:Triton.Logic.ResetSingletonAction
member.summary: Resets a singleton, forcing it to re-initialize on its next usage.
member.remarks:
This action is designed for SingletonBase singletons but will also work with other singletons that meet the following criteria:
Must have a static bool Exists property that indicates if the instance of the singleton has be instantiated.
Must have a reset method to force re-initialization of the singleton.
Returned events: ok - the singleton was successfully reset.
error - an error occurred while attempting to reset the singleton.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: M:Triton.Support.Request.Extensions.GetRequestItem``1(Triton.Controller.Request.MvcRequest,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the item with the specified name from the given MvcRequest's Items collection. Extracts the item from a SearchResult if the item for the given name is a SearchResult<T>. If required is true an exception is thrown if there is no value in the Items collection for the given name, or the object is not of type T. If required is false and there is no item with the given name, or the item is not of type T or SearchResult<T>, the type's default value is returned.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to retrieve.
member.param: The MvcRequest to retrieve the item from.
The name of the item in the request's Items collection to retrieve.
Indicates if the requested item is "required". If true error checking is performed to ensure that a value of the correct type is returned.
member.returns: The item with the specified name from the given MvcRequest's Items collection.

member.name: T:Triton.Logic.SetParameterAction
member.summary: SetParameterAction is an Action that sets the value of one or more request parameters. The name(s) and value(s) of the parameters to be set are defined in the corresponding state's parameters and/or defaults attributes.
member.remarks:
The format of the parameters and defaults attributes is: param1=val1|param2=val2...
where
param1, param2, etc. are the name(s) of the parameter(s) to set the values of, and
val1, val2, etc. are the corresponding value(s) to be assigned to the parameter(s).
The pipe (|) delimits different parameters.
SetParameterAction also supports concatenating of values to a parameter's existing value, and dynamic parameter values.
Concatenation of a value is signified using the "+=" operator instead of "=".
A dynamic value is specified by placing the name of another request parameter within '[' and ']' delimters. The value assigned to the parameter specified for SetParameterAction will be the value of the parameter whose name is included in the value section.
Examples:
param1=1 sets the parameter "param1" to the value "1".
param1=1|param2=abc sets the parameter "param1" to the value "1" and parameter "param2" to the value "abc".
param1+=xyz appends "xyz" to the current value of "param1".
param1+=xyz|param2+=[param1]*abc, assuming "param1" had a value of "1" coming in, sets "param1" to "1xyz" and "param2" to "1xyz*abc"
The defaults attribute acts like the parameters except it only set the parameter value(s) if there is not already a value for the parameter.
Notes:
A parameter may appear only once as parameter to set in a list of pipe-delimited parameters.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: F:Triton.Logic.SetParameterAction.PARAM_VALUE_REGEX
member.summary: The regular expression used to parse parameter value into literal and dynamic components if it contains dynamic delimiters ([]).

member.name: T:Triton.Controller.PageFinder
member.summary: PageFinder handles finding the location of the proper page (aspx file), master page, static content file (xml), image, etc. file based on the version, site, section, and filename.
member.remarks:
The PageFinder searches for files using the following algorithm:
1. Look for {version}/{site}/{section}/{file}.
If the file is a page:
2a. Look for {version}/[configuration["defaultDirName"]/{section}/{file}.
If the file is a content:
2b. Look for {version}/{site}/{language}/{section}/{file}.
3. Get the site's search method.
If search method is defaultDir:
4a. Look for {version}/[configuration["defaultDirName"]/{file}.
If search method is prevVersion:
4b. Repeat search on previous version.
If the master page(s) are stored in a subdirectory from where the aspx page is located, the relative path to the master pages directory is specified in the masterSubPath appSetting in the config file. For example, "/masterpages".
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: T:Triton.Controller.Publish.PublishManager
member.summary: PublishManager is a singleton that manages the information for publishing of pages.
member.remarks:
PublishManager keeps track of published content information by maintaining a PublishPageRecord for each published content in a PublishedPageCollection. The key for the content in the hashtable is {stateId}_{event}_{requestParams}, where:
{stateId} is the ID of the state the event is fired from.
{event} is the name of the event.
{requestParams} is a "_"-delimited list of the values of the request parameters identified by the PublishKeyParams property of the transition corresponding to the event.
PublishManager also maintains a hashtable of the expiration times set for each site. In this hashtable the key is the site code and the value is the expiration time for published pages, in minutes. The expiration time for each site is defined by the pageExpirationTime attribute in sites.config
The publishedPages collection that keeps track of published pages is periodically checked for expired pages by a thread timer. The interval at which the check is made is defined by the pageCheckTime attribute in sites.config. This process removes any page references from the publishedPages were the page has expired.
PublishManager does not itself publish the pages. It provides a PagePublisher, via the GetPublisher method, to perform the actual page publishing. Each PagePublisher is coupled to the HTTP request performing the publish so thread safety is ensured.
The published pages are published to the appropriate sub-directory under the publish directory for the site and section they belong to. The published file name is of the form: {event}_{requestParams}_{page}, where:
{event} is the name of the event the page is generated in response to.
{requestParams} is a "_"-delimited list of the values of the request parameters identified by the PublishKeyParams property of the transition corresponding to the event. {page} is the name of the page.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.remarks: State prerequisite are included in the attributes collection with the attribute name of "prerequisite" and a value in the form of [{name}=]{start_state_id},{start_event}|[{name}=]{start_state_id},{start_event}|... where {name} is the name of the (optional) name of the prerequisite, {start_state_id} is the ID of the start state for the prerequisite flow and {start_event} is the event from the start state to follow. {name} is optional. With no name the value would look like: {start_state_id},{start_event}|{start_state_id},{start_event}|...
member.param: The type of State to make.
The state ID for the state.
A NameValueCollection containing the attributes for the state.
member.returns: A new instance of a State of the specified type.

member.name: T:Triton.Logging.Logger
member.summary: Logger objects are responsible for publishing messages to a data store. There can only be one Logger of a given name, all of which are stored in a Singleton instance of LogManager. Logger objects are instantiated through the static method Logger.GetLogger(loggerName) which will check LogManager first to see if it exists. If not, it will attempt to create the logger dynamically from the Loggers.config file. If this fails (logger does not have predefined settings), a custom Logger is created. Once a Logger is available, call any of the Log methods (or shortcut methods) to have the message processed. When Once these methods are called, the message is validated by checking it's level against the level of the Logger object as well as applying a filter, if available. If it passes, it is added to the message queue for later processing, else nothing. There is a TimerCallback delegate used, one for each unique Logger, to process the queue on a separate thread. This delegate has a timer set so that it processes at the given interval. The process method loops all messages currently in the queue and for each, loops all handlers for the Logger used to publish the message. Any number of Handler objects can be added to a Logger for message processing.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: M:Triton.Logging.Logger.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.remarks: A TimerCallback delegate is used for each instance of Logger so we have one thread that processes the Queue. A timer is set on the deleagate to start the thread and execute it at the specified time interval.
member.param: String that specifies the name of the Logger
member.returns: Logger object

member.name: M:Triton.Logging.Logger.GetLogger(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a Logger object of the desired name and level.
member.param: String that specifies the name of the Logger
member.returns: Logger object

member.summary: Synchronously clears the message queue.

member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: T:Triton.Support.Collections.Cache
member.summary: The Cache is a keyed collection of objects where the objects in the collection are automatically removed at a specified time or interval.
member.remarks:
A Cache can be set up in one of two modes, relative or absolute. In an absolute Cache all items in the cache expire at a specified time of day. In a relative Cache items expire at some amount of time after they were added.
A relative Cache supports the keep alive option. Keep alive resets the clock for an item's expiration each time it is used. This affectively changes the definition of the time interval specified for expiring objects to be from the last time used rather than from the time it was added.
A relative Cache that is set to keep alive can also be set to expire items after a certain amount of time regardless of when they were last used. This is the drop dead time. The drop dead must be greater than the regular expiration time.
member.author: Scott Dyke

member.name: M:Triton.Support.Collections.Cache.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan,Triton.Support.Collections.CacheType)
member.summary: Constructs a Cache of the specified type with the given check interval and item expire time.
member.remarks: A Cache constructed in this manner does not include the keep-alive option.
member.param: The inteval at which to check the cache for expired items.
The time or interval at which items expire from the cache.
The type of cache to construct.

member.name: M:Triton.Support.Collections.Cache.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan,Triton.Support.Collections.CacheType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a Cache of the specified type with the given check interval, item expire time, and keep-alive settings.
member.param: The inteval at which to check the cache for expired items.
The time or interval at which items expire from the cache.
The type of cache to construct.
If true expireTime is from the last time the item was access, if false expireTime is from the time the item was added to the cache.

member.name: M:Triton.Support.Collections.Cache.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan,Triton.Support.Collections.CacheType,System.Boolean,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Constructs a Cache of the specified type with the given check interval, item expire time, keep-alive and drop dead settings.
member.param: The inteval at which to check the cache for expired items.
The time or interval at which items expire from the cache.
The type of cache to construct.
If true expireTime is from the last time the item was access, if false expireTime is from the time the item was added to the cache.

member.summary: Sets up the Timer to periodically call the method to process the queue. Because the timer makes a copy of the given QueueInfo changes to the properties of the queue are not reflected in the timer's state information. So, whenever a property of the FileQueue is changed, the old timer must be disposed and a new one created with the current state info.

member.name: T:Triton.Support.Collections.FileQueue.QueueInfo

These properties represent the state of the FileQueue and are encapsulated in this struct so the state can be given to the Timer that periodically processes the queue, and then given to the processing method. The processing method can use this state information to create a new FileQueue to perform the queue processing.

member.summary:
This function determines the cross product of two Sets. Two cautions should be taken when using CrossProduct:
For large sets, this method can take a long time.
If Set s has any elements that are also in this Set, the list of Sets will contain (one or more) Sets with fewer elements than the majority.
member.param: A second Set to be crossed with the original Set.
member.returns: a Set representing the cross product of two Sets.

member.name: M:Triton.Utilities.StringExtensions.EvaluatePropertyValue(System.String)
member.summary: This method will take the String provided and evaluate the Property/Const value. If no value can be discerned then the origional value is returned for instance "{Triton.Location.Support.Request.ParameterNames+PersistedAddress+Field.LINE1}" this will create a instance of the class Triton.Location.Support.Request.ParameterNames.PersistedAddress.Field and evaluate the value for the constant field "LINE1" the + operators are needed when the class definition is internal to the parent class. so the namespace is "Triton.Location.Support.Request" and the class Parameternames has an internal class PersistedAddress which has an internal class Field. Note: this is only usefull for constants or static Properties.
member.param: MvcRequest
fully qualified class name
member.returns: string representation
